data.title: Freezing on very long Lines
data.body:
Atom Version 1.5.3
Opened CSS File with inline Image, tryd to delete the Image part it hangs/freeze then in
PATH: atom\app-1.5.3\resources\app.asar\src\lines-yardstick.js
Line 59 : while (textIndex < text.length)

In SafeMode it is not freezing

Steps to reproduce:
Create CSS File
Add the Code below
Jump to the End of the Line `background: #fff ...`
Klick on the Text before `=') repeat;`

`body {
    background: #fff url('data:image/png;base64,') repeat;
}
`

data.title: Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'serialize' of undefined when closing last pane
data.body:
As far as I can tell, this started happening recently, after #10737 was merged. /cc @benogle @natalieogle

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open a bunch of files
2. Start closing them one-by-one
3. Exception is thrown after last one is closed

Here's a GIF (notice how the exception doesn't happen when closing or opening files until the last one is closed):

![w](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/38924/13387539/fcf4e866-deb7-11e5-9ab3-7468bdf2d108.gif)

**Atom Version**: 1.7.0-dev-b589e28
**System**: Mac OS X 10.11.3
**Thrown From**: Atom Core

Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'serialize' of undefined

data.title: onDidTerminatePendingState ➡︎ onItemDidTerminatePendingState
data.body: Continuation of #10959

data.title: Building Atom Beta releases so they can be installed simultaneously, on the same machine, to stable releases
data.body:
Hi,

I realize you's are probably getting sick of me by now, but I was wondering if there is some option one can pass to `script/build` or `script/grunt install` to build Atom beta with different installed file paths, so that Atom beta and Atom stable releases can be installed simultaneously on the same machine. See running `script/build && sudo script/grunt install` in the beta branch of this repo will install Atom in the standard file locations (that are also used by the stable releases of Atom) on Linux platforms, at least, as those used by stable Atom releases. So you will get `/usr/bin/atom`, `/usr/bin/apm`, _etc._ files installed at those exact locations, while the Debian and RPM packages provided by this repo for Atom beta releases will install the same files to `/usr/bin/atom-beta`, `/usr/bin/apm-beta`, _etc._ instead and let Atom stable releases use the aforementioned installed file locations (i.e., `/usr/bin/atom`, `/usr/bin/apm`, _etc._) for their installed files. 

This issue means that presently the `atom-editor` and `atom-editor-beta` PKGBUILDs in the Arch User Repository cannot be installed simultaneously, even though `atom-editor` and `atom-editor-beta-bin` can be installed simultaneously because `atom-editor-beta-bin` builds its package from the Debian binary provided for Atom beta releases. 

Thanks for your time,
Brenton

data.body: Time to update some more specs!

data.title: Official Package for Debian Linux / Ubuntu
data.body: Is it possible to create an official package for Debian Linux / Ubuntu for the Advanced Packaging Tool?

data.title: Show tooltip immediately if the tooltip trigger is manual
data.body: https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/10996

data.title: Show tooltip immediately if the tooltip trigger is manual
data.body:
I think tooltips should display immediately for `trigger: 'manual'` (currently, setting that trigger type has no effect).

The Bootstrap tooltip has a `trigger` option that's `click | hover | focus | manual` http://getbootstrap.com/javascript/#tooltips-options For `'manual'` you need to call `show()` on the tooltip to get it to display, but the current Atom tooltip API doesn't expose that method. This makes it hard to get a tooltip to show immediately (e.g. you'd have to set `trigger: 'click'` and dispatch a click event on the target element).

data.title: Can't open multiple non-text files in Atom 1.7.0-dev-a7e43fe
data.body:
@BinaryMuse @kuychaco @nathansobo @lee-dohm Wondering if you could take a look at this one :pray: -- I _think_ it might be related to https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/10959.

Here's what the behavior was prior to  #10959 being merged (at 606dc0299c9e8f2a80a0321ef5cdcc89e933012c, in safe mode):

![problem1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/38924/13378484/982fcb62-de08-11e5-901d-9362a3ee53fd.gif)

Notice that I click through several images, and every one of those opens in a separate tab. 

And here's the behavior on latest master (at a7e43fef7a2dd11ad90c691870aac517fd12ced7, in safe mode):

![problem2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/38924/13378523/88569b98-de09-11e5-867d-3d6a4deca62d.gif)

Notice how each image is replaced and I can't have more than one open. This happens regardless of whether I opened the files with a single click or double click, and regardless of whether I double click the tab after opening a file. In other words, I can't seem to open multiple image files currently. This is also seems to be true for other non-text files (e.g. zip archives). For text files, I can get the expected behavior by opening them with a double click.

Reading [this comment](https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/10959#issuecomment-188920474) by @BinaryMuse, it seems that this behavior might partially be expected. However, I believe users will expect the same behavior for text and non-text files, especially non-text files handled by core packages (e.g. image-view and archive-view). If this isn't something that should be handled in Atom core, I think we should update our packages and possibly warn other package authors about this change and tell them how exactly they should update their packages.

data.title: TextEditor.findMarkers returns all markers related to TextBuffer, not just those related to calling editor
data.body:
This is relevant in case there are multiple `TextEditor`s with the same `TextBuffer` open, e.g. after `split-...` command.

I'm not sure if this is a bug or a feature, but I'd prefer to get _only_ markers related to calling `TextEditor`. Would that be possible without horrible hacks?

data.title: File changes lost when opened in two windows.
data.body:
### Description

I use atom.io for a large project on two monitors with the same project open. Sometimes it happens (especially automatically after reloading atom) that the same file gets open in both the two windows. I worked in one window on one file for really long and put quite some effort into it. As soon as I clicked the same file's already open tab in the other window, the file's content got overwritten by the content version of the second window (~250 lines became 1 line, lost hours of work). No undo. Couldn't find a way to get it back.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open two atom windows. Use Add Project Folder... for the same folders in the two windows. Open a file in both windows.
2. Modify the file in one window.
3. Click the other window, the tab of the same file.
4. The file gets reverted and saved, no way to get your work back.

**Expected behavior:** The content in the second window should be updated. Or at least shouldn't overwrite the other file without question.

**Actual behavior:** As soon as you give focus to the other window it overwrites the file without question with the previous content. 
### Versions

1.5.3

2. Create a React object in it.

data.title: Scrolling Performance of ScrollBarComponent
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

Scrolling causes my Macbook to heat up and is generally pretty choppy. It appears that there's some low hanging fruit in the scroll bar component. Anywhere from 20-40% of the time in scrolling is spent updating the ScrollBarComponent! I would rather have no scrollbar, than one that causes my laptop to heat up - is there a way to disable it? See the attached image - there's some expensive layout happening when changing the `scrollTop`.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. [Scroll]
2. [Observe laptop get hot/frames drop]
3. [and so on...]

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line.
1.6 beta 4

data.title: Suggestion: "Smart Tab" behaviour
data.body: If somebody asked me to imagine a perfect world, it'd be one where coders used hard tabs for indentation, and spaces to align all code after a non-whitespace character. While this world will never exist, it does illustrate a potentially useful addition to Atom: a fourth tab-type option, which I'm calling _"smart tab"_ for the purpose of this issue: Basically, the editor switches between hard tabs for indentation and spaces depending on whether or not there's a non-whitespace character before the cursor.

data.title: atom.packages.resolvePackagePath(name) works incorrectly when directory with given name exists in current working directory
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

atom.packages.resolvePackagePath(name) works incorrectly when directory with given name exists in current working directory. 
### Steps to Reproduce

Run the following commands in Developer Tools Console.

``` js
> packageName = atom.packages.getAvailablePackageNames()[42]
< "autocomplete-html"
> atom.packages.resolvePackagePath(packageName)
< "/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/node_modules/autocomplete-html"
> require('fs').mkdir(packageName)
> atom.packages.resolvePackagePath(packageName)
< "autocomplete-html"
```

**Expected behavior:** Resolved path must be an actual package path.

**Actual behavior:** Resolved path may be a relative path to existing directory.
### Versions

```
$ atom --version
1.5.3
```

```
$ apm --version
apm  1.6.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.6
git 1.9.1
```
### Proposal

[This line](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/3b309792a531fb809d29c6742de956f50b3acec5/src/package-manager.coffee#L173) may be changed to the following:

``` coffee
return name if name !== path.basename(name) and fs.isDirectorySync(name)
```

data.title: Very very slow with lots of imports when editing RAML
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [X] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [X] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [X] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)?
- [X] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [X] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [X] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

When editing a RAML file with lots (like 10) include directives, performance gets very slow.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Create 10 RAML resource types in 10 files.
2. Include all 10 RAML libraries.
3. Try documenting an API.

**Expected behavior:** 
Editor performs quickly enough that typing appears instantaneously.   I'm  on a 2015 MBP with 8gb ram, SSD drive and 2.7ghz CPU on El Capitan.  We can reproduce this on other computers at our company as well, so it's not hardware dependent
**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
It can take a few seconds for typed characters to show.
### Versions

v1.5.3

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line.

data.title: Portable switch issue
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- Do not have existing `~/.atom`
- Have `[binary-dir]/.atom`
### Description

Switch `--portable` has description:

```
Set portable mode. Copies the ~/.atom folder to be a sibling of the
 installed Atom location if a .atom folder is not already there.
```

So, it should two things:
1. Sets portable mode i.e. use `[binary-dir]/.atom`
2. Copy from `~/.atom` to `[binary-dir]/.atom` if it is still does not exist

But if you do not have `~/.atom` it throws error and ignores setting portable mode
What is strange: it should not to try to check `~/.atom` if there is already existing `[binary-dir]/.atom`

As i understand it works from assumption that `~/.atom` exists
But i think it should be properly handled to when it does not exist too.
At least portable mode should be set.

```
Failed copying portable directory 'C:\Users\Douman\.atom' to 'E:\Soft\Main\.atom'
ENOENT: no such file or directory, scandir 'C:\Users\Douman\.atom' Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, scandir 'C:\Users\Douman\.atom'
    at Error (native)
    at Object.fs.readdirSync (fs.js:813:18)
    at Object.fs.readdirSync (ATOM_SHELL_ASAR.js:454:28)
    at Object.fsPlus.copySync (E:\Soft\Main\Atom\resources\app.asar\node_modules\fs-plus\lib\fs-plus.js:325:20)
    at Function.module.exports.AtomPortable.setPortable (E:\Soft\Main\Atom\resources\app.asar\src\browser\atom-portable.js:20:17)
    at setupAtomHome (E:\Soft\Main\Atom\resources\app.asar\src\browser\main.js:101:22)
    at start (E:\Soft\Main\Atom\resources\app.asar\src\browser\main.js:33:5)
    at Object.<anonymous> (E:\Soft\Main\Atom\resources\app.asar\src\browser\main.js:209:3)
    at Object.<anonymous> (E:\Soft\Main\Atom\resources\app.asar\src\browser\main.js:211:4)
    at Module._compile (module.js:434:26)
```
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Run atom first time to create `~/.atom`
2. Copy `~/.atom` into `[binary-dir]`
3. Delete  `~/.atom` 
4. Run `./atom.exe --portable`

**Expected behavior:** portable mode set and `[binary-dir]/.atom` is used

**Actual behavior:** portable mode is not set and `~/.atom` is used
### Versions

1.5.3
### Note

The portable look-up is not working when you run just Atom.
Even if i have `[binary-dir]/.atom` it is ignored for some reason

data.title: Disentangling `TextEditor` dependencies and reviving the use of the constructor
data.body:
@joshaber and I were talking this morning about how unfortunate it is to require `TextEditor` instances to be constructed via the `atom.workspace.buildTextEditor` factory method instead of just via a normal constructor.

In https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/8968, we disentangled all the global references and moved to straight dependency injection. Because `TextEditor` had many dependencies, at that time we decided to deprecate the `TextEditor` export in the module returned by `require('atom')` and encourage people to use the factory so that these dependencies could be injected by the method without references to globals.

Now we're realizing that was probably a mistake. If you look at the dependencies of `TextEditor`, all but `clipboard` can actually be eliminated via various approaches. Some of them absolutely _should_ be eliminated, because we're using them to subscribe to global events such as `atom.grammars.onDidAddGrammar`. This creates a requirement that package authors call `destroy` on `TextEditor` instances they construct or otherwise they leak editor instances because these subscriptions are never disposed. Other dependencies _can_ be eliminated in various ways but aren't actually causing leaks.

Let's go through injected dependencies one at a time:
- [x] `notificationManager` This is for notifying the user of the cursor scope. We can add a `getCursorScope` method and implement this elsewhere as well.
- [x] `packageManager` This is just to emit grammar loaded hooks. Again, seems like we could emit events on individual editors and do this elsewhere.
- [x] `viewRegistry` We won't need this at all if people implement `getElement`.
- [x] `project` We set the project's path when the file is saved for the first time. Doesn't need to happen inside editor.
- [x] `assert` A method for sending stack traces of unexpected states to the exception tracker. We don't necessarily need this everywhere and could even maybe look the other way using a global.
- [x] `applicationDelegate` This is used to open prompts about file size. Could be moved and hopefully someday won't matter.
- [ ] `grammarRegistry` Again, when grammars are loaded, match them against editors from the outside.
- [ ] `config` Everything this controls can be managed from the outside (the workspace) and set options on the `TextEditor` directly. The only downside is that it would make it harder for package authors to match the settings of editors in panes.
- [ ] `clipboard` This one is needed or you can't copy and paste. But could we have a private global for it via the module system. Essentially a singleton you `require`?

Some of these cases are more clear than others. What's less clear for me is the config and grammar registry. What if the package author _wants_ a grammar to be automatically assigned based on the editor's path? What if they want to follow along with the user's settings for editors in panes?

I don't have perfect answers to these questions yet. It could be that the newly proposed editor registration API could also hook up your editor with certain services such as automatic grammar assignment and tracking certain user settings. Bottom line is, unless we want to bet on every editor user to calling _destroy_ when they're done with our instance at the risk of leaking editors, these dependencies have to go anyway.

Thoughts? Tweaks? /cc @atom/core @maxbrunsfeld @joshaber

data.title: Subpixel font rendering is not working / inferior
data.body:
This issue is related to Chrome (or Chromium) and not specific to atom. But I am seeing it in atom as well.
It may be an issue specific to Mac OS X 10.11.3.

I am posting it in atom because... well I could be wrong so having other people be able to confirm this would be great. If there _is_ an issue, then it's mutually beneficial for atom to also raise attention to have this fixed in chromium.

---

I noticed text in atom look pretty good, but Sublime always looked better. And I looked more closely and the rendering doesn't look like it's using subpixel rendering but instead some sort of grayscale. 

After double checking with 
`-webkit-font-smoothing: subpixel-antialiased;` 
I could not get a different result. So I decided to see if in Chrome it does better rendering, and I see the same result in Chrome. So I wondered if this existed in Firefox or Safari, it does not. In Firefox and Safari the font rendering look similar. And they look similar to what I am seeing in Sublime.

The report on chromium side is here: https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=581166

In the attached picture, this is the result I am seeing when comparing 3 browsers, they are a close up of a piece of text being rendered on webpages (github homepage in this specific picture).
![chrome-safari-firefox](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/25837/13341888/93dab900-dc0a-11e5-9b2f-757397100d1e.png)

I used the Digital Color Meter app in OS X to zoom in on the pixels, and then looked at the same page on all 3 browsers while taking that screen grab. Ideally I should've shown the picture example on a webpage that was "neutral" where I know for sure the CSS wasn't affecting the font rendering. But the issue exists no matter what page you are viewing, and also exists in atom.

The results I am seeing between chrome and safari / firefox is the same thing as when comparing atom and sublime.

So far  I and the original bug report creator (on chromium) are both running OS X 10.11.3. So whether this exists in any other OS X version, or another OS, I don't know.
